text: OF TACITUS. 379 was nothing to fear. His gluttony (a) knew no bounds. To administer to his appetite, Rome and Italy were ransacked for rarities. The roads from both the seas rung with a din of carriages, loaded with whatever was exquisite to the palate. To entertain him on his march, the principal men of every city were obliged to lavish all their wealth, and the country was ex- hausted. The soldiers, degenerating into a band of epicures, lost all regard for mi- litary duty. They despised their prince, yet followed his example. Vitellius, by an edict sent forward to Rome, signified his pleasure to postpone for the present the title of Augustus; and for that of Caesar, he declined, it altogether. The prerogative of the prince was sufficient for his ambition. He ordered the mathe- maticians to be banished out of Italy, and, under heavy penalties, restrained the Roman knights from disgracing themselves by fighting prizes like common gladiators, and by exhibiting their persons on the public stage.
